Corn (maize) Common Rust: The leaves of corn plants have small, round to elongated brownish-red pustules on both sides. As the crop matures, these pustules turn dark brown and release spores. In severe cases, the infection spreads to the sheath and other parts of the plant. The pustules on sweet corn are mostly susceptible to this disease, with only a few varieties showing resistance. Corn plants that show symptoms of chlorotic or necrotic spots may not release as many spores. This disease thrives in cool, warm, and moist weather.

Pustules develop as circular, elongated, or oval on both sides of leaves.* Mature pustules turn dark brown or black and release dark brown spores. Temperature range: 15-25 C. Cool, warm, and moist weather favors the disease.

The pathogen, a soil-borne fungus that infects corn leaves and other plant tissues. Symptoms first appear as small, white or brownish patches on the leaf surface, which expand to form a cotton-like mass of spores called sclerotia. The sclerotia eventually develop into hard, dark brown nodules (scleroconia) that rupture and release spores.

The leaves of sweet corn plants display small, round to elongated cinnamon-colored, eruptive pustules that are dusty and powdery. Redhead mold (Botryotium pyriformis) is a fungal pathogen that infects sweet corn plants. At the start of infection, small flecks appear on both sides of leaves. As the plant matures, brownish-black pustules develop on both leaf surfaces. If infection is severe, it can spread to the sheath and other parts of the plant. The pustules are oval or elongated and cinnamon brown in color, rupturing to release powdery red spores. As they mature, the pustules may appear on tassles.

However, some corn hybrids are resistant to this disease, but only partially so. The disease spreads quickly when temperatures range from 15 to 25 degrees Celsius and cool, warm, and humid weather is favorable. Wind-borne spores can spread the disease, and many popular sweet corn varieties have little resistance.

However, some corn hybrids are resistant to this disease and exhibit only slight chlorotic or necrotic flecks on their leaves.

Small dark brown spots appear on both sides of leaves. These spots are circular to elongated and erupt with a reddish-brown powder, while older pustules turn black and release dark brown spores. Spores are produced on the underside of the leaf below the lesions, giving it a dusty black/green fuzz appearance. The leaves become greyish-green and brittle, resembling leaves killed by frost.

Lesions run parallel to leaf margins and coalesce, covering the entire leaf surface. Spores are produced on the underside of the leaves. Beneath the lesions, a fungus gives a dusty black/green fuzz appearance. The leaves become greyish-green and brittle, resembling frostbitten foliage.

Grape Black Rot: Reddish-brown lesions on the upper surface of leaves may be circular or angular, ranging from 2 to over 100 in number per leaf depending on severity. The center turns tannish brown and is surrounded by a black margin. Fruiting bodies form just inside the margin. Only young, rapidly growing leaves are affected.Lesions appear irregularly shaped (2-25 mm) and initially reddish-brown, turning black later. If severe, lesions may coalesce and similar to black rot on berries with clusters.

Grapevine leaves exhibit reddish-brown spots that may coalesce into larger, irregular blotches. Lesion size ranges from 2mm to 25mm in diameter. On the underside of the leaves, water-soaked gray lesions may form, turning purple and necrotic in the center, causing a shot hole appearance if the lesion drops out. If many lesions are present on the leaves, they can become chlorotic and fall from the tree.

Red to purple leaf spots can range from 2 to 10 millimeters in diameter with a yellow halo. The most common areas for these spots are the tips of leaves and along midribs. When diseased, leaves rapidly turn yellow and fall off trees even with minimal spotting. The shot-hole appearance is caused by spots expanding and centers dropping out.Dark blue, water soaked, angular gray lesions occur on the underside of leaves which can turn purple and necrotic at their center before the fruit appears. These lesions can cause a shot hole appearance.

Red to purple spots appear as small, angular patches with a yellow halo on the surface of leaves. These spots are typically found at the tips of leaves and along midribs, although they can also occur randomly. If these spots rapidly develop into necrotic centers, the resulting shot-hole symptom may cause the leaf to drop from the tree.On the underside of affected leaves, there are water-soaked, angular gray lesions that may eventually become purple and necrotic in the center, creating a shot hole appearance.

Red to purple spots are small and angular with a yellow halo. Lesions form on the underside of leaves, usually in areas that are water-soaked. These lesions turn purple and necrotic at their centers, resulting in shot-hole symptoms. If there are numerous lesions, leaves may drop prematurely from trees. The likelihood of fruit and leaf infection increases during periods of frequent rainfall during late bloom and early petal drop; however, infection is rare during hot, dry weather.

Red to purple leaf spots with a yellow halo are small and angular in shape, often appearing on the leaf tips or along the midribs. The yellow-bordered red to purple spots range from minute to medium in size and are angular. Typically they occur on the tips of leaves and along midribs; however, on infected branches diseased leaves rapidly turn yellow and drop. Spots expand and centers drop out, resulting in shot-hole symptoms. Water soaked lesions, occurring as reddish-purple necrotic areas on the underside of leaves, cause a shot hole appearance if their centers drop out; high numbers of these can be detrimental to the tree's health.

Red to purple leaf spots are small and angular with a yellow halo. They usually occur on the tips of leaves and along midribs. Red to purple spots appear as small, angular areas with a yellow border on leaves. The majority of these spots are positioned on leaf tips and along the veins of the leaves. Waterlogged spots that dry out and turn brown form on the underside of leaves. This disease thrives in warm, wet conditions.

Tomato Target Spot: the disease is characterized by small, water-soaked spots on the upper surfaces of tomato leaves that develop into necrotic lesions with light brown centers and dark margins. These symptoms can be mistaken for bacterial spot. As the lesions grow, they become circular with gray to pale brown centers and may develop concentric circles similar to those seen on early blight lesions. Lesions may also have yellow halos. Larger lesions coalesce into areas with high percentages of affected leaflets, and infected leaves may drop prematurely.

As the spots develop, they turn into necrotic lesions with light brown centers and dark margins. The symptoms enlarge over time and become circular with gray to pale brown centers, eventually forming concentric circles similar to those seen on early blight lesions. A yellow halo can form around the lesions in some varieties. Lesions may coalesce and lead to large blighted areas on the leaflets.
